questions.text:
A child is diagnosed with hypertrophic pyloric stenosis, which among the following can be seen in this child?
A. Bilious vomiting
B. Epigastric mass with Visible peristalsis
C. Hypochloremia and hypokalemia
D. Metabolic alkalosis
questions.solution:
In CHPS(Congenital Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis) obstruction is at pyloric part of stomach means obstruction is before opening of the ampulla of the vater, that's why vomiting will be non bilious vomiting.

Vomiting in Congenital Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis


Visible peristalsis from left to right/ Palpable mass

On inspection visible peristalsis from left to right

On palpation olive shaped lump in epigastrium

Hypochloremic hypokalemiac Metabolic alkalosis in CHPS

In Chronic Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis (CHPS), persistent vomiting causes loss of hydrogen (H+) and chloride (Cl-) ions, leading to hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis. Fluid loss activates RAAS, and elevated aldosterone promotes sodium and water reabsorption while increasing potassium (K+) and hydrogen (H+) excretion, resulting in hypokalemia.

Key takeaways of CHPS

Definition:

Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS) is the thickening of the pyloric muscle, causing obstruction from the stomach to the duodenum.

Epidemiology:

Age of presentation:2week-3month

More Common in male than female child

Clinical Presentation:

Projectile Vomiting: Non-bilious, progressing to projectile vomiting after feeding. Olive-Shaped epigastric Mass (Hallmark feature)

Dehydration and Weight Loss: Resulting from poor food retention.

Diagnosis:

Ultrasound: First-line tool & IOC showing thickened pyloric muscle.

Blood Tests: reveal hypochloremic, hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis due to prolonged vomiting.

Treatment:

Surgical Intervention (Pyloromyotomy): Ramstedt pyloromyotomy is the definitive treatment Preoperative Stabilization: Correct dehydration and electrolyte imbalances before surgery. Prognosis:Excellent prognosis with full recovery expected post-surgery.

Reference: Nelson textbook of paediatric

questions.text: Transplacental transmission of the organism given in the image which causes microcephaly in the newborn is?
questions.solution:
• Mother infected with Zika virus, transmitted by Aedes mosquito
  • Infection involves Hofbauer cells in placenta
  • Virus crosses placenta, reaching the fetus
  • Damages developing glial cells, causing microcephaly

Incorrect options:

Rubella


CMV


HSV


Key takeaway


Reference: Nelson textbook of paediatric

questions.text: Which among the following intrauterine infection produces hydrocephalus in the baby?
questions.solution:
Most of the congenital infections have either small sized head or normal sized head.only one infection has large sized head(hydrocephalus) that is toxoplasmosis.

Other options:

(A): Rubella: there is microcephaly in CRS(Congenital Rubella Syndrome)

(B): HSV: There may be microcephaly in Congenital HSV infection.

(C): CMV: There is microcephaly in Congenital CMV infection.

Key takeaways:

Congenital Toxoplasmosis occurs when Toxoplasma gondii is transmitted from mother to fetus.

Classic triad of Congenital toxoplasmosis

I) Hydrocephalus

ii) Diffuse intracranial calcification

iii) Focal chorioretinitis

Diagnosis: Serology, PCR, and imaging (ultrasound, CT, MRI).

Treatment: Pyrimethamine, sulfadiazine with folinic acid; corticosteroids for severe cases. Prevention: Pregnant women should avoid cat litter, undercooked meat, and unwashed produce.

Reference: Nelson textbook of paediatric

questions.text: A 7-year-old male child has complaints of nocturnal bed-wetting twice per week. Evaluation was done and revealed no organic cause. What shall be the initial treatment approach in this child?
questions.solution:
• Primary Nocturnal Enuresis: Bed-wetting twice a week with no organic cause; treatment if not resolved by age 6.

First-Line Treatment: Behavioral Modification/Non pharmacological Therapy - Lifestyle Modification: Restrict fluids after 6-7 PM; divide daytime fluids (40% before lunch, 40% before dinner, 20% at dinner).

  • Bed Alarm System: Moisture-sensitive pad triggers alarm to wake the child and interrupt urination.
  • Motivational Therapy: 25% success rate; reassurance and reward charts for dry nights.

Other options

(B): Oral Imipramine

Imipramine is A TCA(Tri Cyclic Antidepressant) class drug,which inhibits Norepinephrine & Serotonin reuptake.it also has anticholinergic property acting on M3 receptor of bladder it relaxes bladder.

(D): Oral Desmopressin

Desmopressin is V2(vasopressin receptor type2) Agonist.it comes in formulation iv & oral. it is drug of choice in Mild vWF deficiency,Hemophilia A,Central Diabetes Insipidus,Nocturnal enuresis.

Key takeaways

Nocturnal enuresis/Bed wetting: Involuntary urination during sleep in children ≥5 years old - More common in boys

Types

  1. Primary Nocturnal Enuresis: No prolonged dry period since birth
  2. Secondary Nocturnal Enuresis: Bed-wetting after ≥6months of dryness

Treatment: Treatment should be started if nocturnal enuresis doesn't improve by 6yrs.

1st line treatment: Behavioral modification/Non pharmacological Therapy

I)Life style modification(LSM)

ii)Bed alarm system/Bell & ped alarm system

iii)Motivational therapy

2nd line treatment:Pharmacologic Treatment(if behavioral methods fail)

I)oral Desmopressin(drug): Decreases nighttime urine production

ii)oral Imipramine:Used cautiously due to side effects

Reference: Nelson textbook of paediatric

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl presented with firm, non-tender, palpable masses on the left side of neck. The swellings were slowly increasing in size but non-pulsatile. Examination revealed Axillary Freckles bilaterally and multiple brown flat skin lesions on the trunk. Likely diagnosis of the masses?
questions.solution:
In given case scenario firm,non tender palpable mass non pulsatile mass which is slowly growing bilateral axillary freckles and multiple brown flat skin lesions on trunk which also known as café-au-lait spots, which are classic signs of NF1.So likely diagnosis is plexiform neurofibroma.

Other options

(A) Chemodectoma

Chemodectoma is usually pulsatile and associated with carotid body tumors.

(B) Lipoma

Lipoma is typically soft, rubbery ,mobile, and not associated with NF1.

(C) Cystic hygroma

soft, compressible, especially in the posterior

Key takeaways:

Reference: Nelson textbook of paediatric
